timeline.message:
FISH-661 Upgrade MP JWT Auth to 1.2-RC2

Signed-off-by: Matthew Gill <matthew.gill@live.co.uk>

FISH-661 JWT Auth 1.2 Boolean Claim Conversion

When injecting boolean claims, the injection failed as the JsonValue was
unmodified. This change properly converts the value to a boolean.

Signed-off-by: Matthew Gill <matthew.gill@live.co.uk>

FISH-661 MP JWT Auth 1.2 Add additional expiry check

The TCK now checks for a token with an invalid issue time, which wasn't
previously checked.

Signed-off-by: Matthew Gill <matthew.gill@live.co.uk>

FISH-661 MP JWT Auth 1.2 Groups Not Required

The 'groups' claim is no longer required, so the validation no longer
requires it. A new TCK test 'callEchoNoGroups' checks that the principal
is still set when @PermitAll endpoints are called. To fix this, I've
enabled the JWT request filter even when this is found, but disabled
most of the logic.

Signed-off-by: Matthew Gill <matthew.gill@live.co.uk>

replies.bodyText: I wanted to ask for feedback on this actually. I did this because I noted that whenever a request was unsuccessful it wasn't clear to me why without debugging. This said, do you think this will be a little too spammy?

replies.bodyText: I know very little about the context here - would it log with basically every request of a session that had this problem or is it more once when trying to login?

replies.bodyText: I think that it should only trigger when a JWT Token is provided, so I don't think it's too invasive. I just thought it would be beneficial to see why a token is being rejected

timeline.bodyText:
I see that file already contain Class comparison using equals.
As it is not reasonable to have two equal instances of a Class unless they are in fact identical I would generally suggest to not shy away from using the == and != operators when working with Classes.
timeline.author: jbee

timeline.message:
FISH-661 Minor JWT Auth RequestFilter refactor

The requestfilter permitAll constructor had an unused variable so this
change removes it. The XOR was confusing, so it's been replaced with a
logical operator. Classes cannot be equal unless they are identical, so
the installCoreConverter has been made null safe by using ==.

Signed-off-by: Matthew Gill <matthew.gill@live.co.uk>
